words.def: A category is abelian if it has a zero object, it has all pullbacks and pushouts, and all monomorphisms and epimorphisms are normal.
words.name: abelian

words.def:
1.  Given a cardinal number κ, an object X in a category is κ-accessible (or κ-compact or κ-presentable) if 
  
    
      
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        −
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} (X,-)}
  
 commutes with κ-filtered colimits.
words.name: accessible

words.def: A category is additive if it is preadditive and admits all finitary biproducts. Although "preadditive" is an additional structure, one can show "additive" is a property of a category; i.e., one can ask whether a given category is additive or not.
words.name: additive

words.def:
An adjunction (also called an adjoint pair) is a pair of functors F: C → D, G: D → C such that there is a "natural" bijection


  
    
      
        
          Hom
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        F
        (
        X
        )
        ,
        Y
        )
        ≃
        
          Hom
          
            C
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        G
        (
        Y
        )
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} _{D}(F(X),Y)\simeq \operatorname {Hom} _{C}(X,G(Y))}
  
;

F is said to be left adjoint to G and G to right adjoint to F. Here, "natural" means there is a natural isomorphism 
  
    
      
        
          Hom
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        F
        (
        −
        )
        ,
        −
        )
        ≃
        
          Hom
          
            C
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        −
        ,
        G
        (
        −
        )
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} _{D}(F(-),-)\simeq \operatorname {Hom} _{C}(-,G(-))}
  
 of bifunctors (which are contravariant in the first variable.)
words.name: adjunction

words.def: A functor is amnestic if it has the property: if k is an isomorphism and F(k) is an identity, then k is an identity.
words.name: amnestic

words.def: A category is balanced if every bimorphism is an isomorphism.
words.name: balanced

words.def:
A bifunctor from a pair of categories C and D to a category E is a functor C × D → E. For example, for any category C, 
  
    
      
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        −
        ,
        −
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} (-,-)}
  
 is a bifunctor from Cop and C to Set.
words.name: bifunctor

words.def: A bimorphism is a morphism that is both an epimorphism and a monomorphism.
words.name: bimorphism

words.def: See Bousfield localization.
words.name: Bousfield localization

words.def: The calculus of functors is a technique of studying functors in the manner similar to the way a function is studied via its Taylor series expansion; whence, the term "calculus".
words.name: calculus of functors

words.def: A category is cartesian closed if it has a terminal object and that any two objects have a product and exponential.
words.name: cartesian closed

words.def: 1.  Given a functor π: C → D (e.g., a prestack over schemes), a morphism f: x → y in C is π-cartesian if, for each object z in C, each morphism g: z → y in C and each morphism v: π(z) → π(x) in D such that π(g) = π(f) ∘ v, there exists a unique morphism u: z → x such that π(u) = v and g = f ∘ u.
words.name: cartesian morphism

words.def: A commutative diagram that is isomorphic to the diagram given as a fiber product.
words.name: Cartesian square

words.def: The term "categorification" is an informal term referring to a process of replacing sets and set-theoretic concepts with categories and category-theoretic concepts in some nontrivial way to capture categoric flavors. Decategorification is the reverse of categorification.
words.name: categorification

words.def:
A category consists of the following data

A class of objects,
For each pair of objects X, Y, a set 
  
    
      
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        Y
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} (X,Y)}
  
, whose elements are called morphisms from X to Y,
For each triple of objects X, Y, Z, a map (called composition)


  
    
      
        ∘
        :
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        Y
        ,
        Z
        )
        ×
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        Y
        )
        →
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        Z
        )
        ,
        
        (
        g
        ,
        f
        )
        ↦
        g
        ∘
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle \circ :\operatorname {Hom} (Y,Z)\times \operatorname {Hom} (X,Y)\to \operatorname {Hom} (X,Z),\,(g,f)\mapsto g\circ f}
  
,


For each object X, an identity morphism 
  
    
      
        
          id
          
            X
          
        
        ∈
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        X
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {id} _{X}\in \operatorname {Hom} (X,X)}
  


subject to the conditions: for any morphisms 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        X
        →
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:X\to Y}
  
, 
  
    
      
        g
        :
        Y
        →
        Z

 and 
  
    
      
        h
        :
        Z
        →
        W
      
    
    {\displaystyle h:Z\to W}
  
,


  
    
      
        (
        h
        ∘
        g

        f

        h

        (
        g
        ∘
        f

    {\displaystyle (h\circ g)\circ f=h\circ (g\circ f)}
  
 and 
  
    
      
        
          id
          
            Y

        f

        f

        =
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {id} _{Y}\circ f=f\circ \operatorname {id} _{X}=f}
  
.

For example, a partially ordered set can be viewed as a category: the objects are the elements of the set and for each pair of objects x, y, there is a unique morphism 
  
    
      
        x
        →
        y
      
    
    {\displaystyle x\to y}
  
 if and only if 
  
    
      
        x
        ≤
        y
      
    
    {\displaystyle x\leq y}
  
; the associativity of composition means transitivity.
words.name: category

words.def: The category of (small) categories, denoted by Cat, is a category where the objects are all the categories which are small with respect to some fixed universe and the morphisms are all the functors.
words.name: category of categories

words.def: The classifying space of a category C is the geometric realization of the nerve of C.
words.name: classifying space

words.def: Often used synonymous with op-; for example, a colimit refers to an op-limit in the sense that it is a limit in the opposite category. But there might be a distinction; for example, an op-fibration is not the same thing as a cofibration.
words.name: co-

        C

          ∫
          
            c
            ∈
            C
          
        
        F
        (
        c
        ,
        c

.

For example, if R is a ring, M a right R-module and N a left R-module, then the tensor product of M and N is

            R

where R is viewed as a category with one object whose morphisms are the elements of R.
words.name: coend

        g

        A

        B
      
    
    {\displaystyle f,g:A\to B}

words.name: coequalizer

The coimage of a morphism f: X → Y is the coequalizer of 
  
    
      
        X
        
          ×
          
            Y
          
        
        X
        ⇉
        X
      
    
    {\displaystyle X\times _{Y}X\rightrightarrows X}
  
.
words.name: coimage

        .

 For example, if f is the identity functor and g is the constant functor with a value b, then it is the slice category of B over an object b.
words.name: comma

words.def: Probably synonymous with #accessible.
words.name: compact

words.def: A category is complete if all small limits exist.
words.name: complete

words.def: A concrete category C is a category such that there is a faithful functor from C to Set; e.g., Vec, Grp and Top.
words.name: concrete

words.def:
A cone is a way to express the universal property of a colimit (or dually a limit). One can show[2] that the colimit 
  
    
      
        
          
            
              lim
              
                
              
            
            →
          
          
            
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \varinjlim }

        Δ
        :
        C
        →
        Fct
        ⁡
        (
        I
        ,
        C
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \Delta :C\to \operatorname {Fct} (I,C)}
  
, which sends an object X to the constant functor with value X; that is, for any X and any functor 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        I
        →
        C
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:I\to C}
  
,


  
    
      
        Hom
        ⁡
        (

        f

        X

            X

        ,

provided the colimit in question exists. The right-hand side is then the set of cones with vertex X.[3]
words.name: cone

A category is connected if, for each pair of objects x, y, there exists a finite sequence of objects zi such that 
  
    
      
        
          z
          
            0

        x

 is nonempty for any i.
words.name: connected

words.def: A conservative functor is a functor that reflects isomorphisms. Many forgetful functors are conservative, but the forgetful functor from Top to Set is not conservative.
words.name: conservative functor

words.def:
A functor is constant if it maps every object in a category to the same object A and every morphism to the identity on A. Put in another way, a functor 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        C
        →
        D
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:C\to D}
  
 is constant if it factors as: 
  
    
      
        C
        →
        {
        A
        }
        
          
            →
            i
          
        
        D
      
    
    {\displaystyle C\to \{A\}{\overset {i}{\to }}D}
  
 for some object A in D, where i is the inclusion of the discrete category { A }.
words.name: constant

words.def:

        )

        (
        S
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle {\mathfrak {P}}(f):{\mathfrak {P}}(T)\to {\mathfrak {P}}(S)}
  


by sending a subset A of T to the pre-image 
  
    
      
        
          f
          
            −
            1
          
        
        (
        A

    {\displaystyle f^{-1}(A)}
  
. With this, 
  
    
      
        
          
            P

          S
          e

          S

    {\displaystyle {\mathfrak {P}}:\mathbf {Set} \to \mathbf {Set} }
  
 is a contravariant functor.
words.name: contravariant functor

words.def:
The coproduct of a family of objects Xi in a category C indexed by a set I is the inductive limit

            i
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle I\to C,\,i\mapsto X_{i}}
  
, where I is viewed as a discrete category. It is the dual of the product of the family. For example, a coproduct in Grp is a free product.
words.name: coproduct

.[4]
words.name: Day convolution

Given categories I, C, the diagonal functor is the functor


  
    
      
        Δ

        C

    {\displaystyle \Delta _{f,i}:\Delta _{A}(i)=A\to \Delta _{B}(i)=B}
  
 that is f at each i.
words.name: diagonal functor

words.def: A differential graded category is a category whose Hom sets are equipped with structures of differential graded modules. In particular, if the category has only one object, it is the same as a differential graded module.
words.name: differential graded category

words.def: A category is discrete if each morphism is an identity morphism (of some object). For example, a set can be viewed as a discrete category.
words.name: discrete

words.def:
The end of a functor 
  
    
      
        F

          C
          
            op
          
        
        ×
        C
        →
        X

            c

        F

        c
        ,

        (

            #
          
        
        :
        
          C
          
            #
          
        
        →
        X

where

 is the category (called the subdivision category of C) whose objects are symbols

 for all objects c and all morphisms u in C and whose morphisms are

 and

 if 
  
    
      
        u
        :
        b

    {\displaystyle u:b\to c}
  
 and where

 is induced by F so that

    {\displaystyle c^{\#}}
  
 would go to

 and

 would go to

. For example, for functors

,

is the set of natural transformations from F to G. For more examples, see this mathoverflow thread. The dual of an end is a coend.
words.name: end

words.def:
Given a monoidal category (C, ⊗, 1), a category enriched over C is, informally, a category whose Hom sets are in C. More precisely, a category D enriched over C is a data consisting of

A class of objects,
For each pair of objects X, Y in D, an object 
  
    
      
        
          Map
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        Y
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Map} _{D}(X,Y)}
  
 in C, called the mapping object from X to Y,
For each triple of objects X, Y, Z in D, a morphism in C,


  
    
      
        ∘
        :
        
          Map
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        Y
        ,
        Z
        )
        ⊗
        
          Map
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        Y
        )
        →
        
          Map
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        Z
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \circ :\operatorname {Map} _{D}(Y,Z)\otimes \operatorname {Map} _{D}(X,Y)\to \operatorname {Map} _{D}(X,Z)}
  
,
called the composition,


For each object X in D, a morphism 
  
    
      
        
          1
          
            X
          
        
        :
        1
        →
        
          Map
          
            D
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        X
        ,
        X
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle 1_{X}:1\to \operatorname {Map} _{D}(X,X)}
  
 in C, called the unit morphism of X

subject to the conditions that (roughly) the compositions are associative and the unit morphisms act as the multiplicative identity. For example, a category enriched over sets is an ordinary category.
words.name: enriched category

words.def: The empty category is a category with no object. It is the same thing as the empty set when the empty set is viewed as a discrete category.
words.name: empty

words.def:
A morphism f is an epimorphism if 
  
    
      
        g
        =
        h
      
    
    {\displaystyle g=h}
  
 whenever 
  
    
      
        g
        ∘
        f
        =
        h
        ∘
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle g\circ f=h\circ f}
  
. In other words, f is the dual of a monomorphism.
words.name: epimorphism

words.def:
The equalizer of a pair of morphisms 
  
    
      
        f
        ,
        g
        :
        A
        →
        B
      
    
    {\displaystyle f,g:A\to B}
  
 is the limit of the pair. It is the dual of a coequalizer.
words.name: equalizer

words.def: 1.  A functor is an equivalence if it is faithful, full and essentially surjective.
words.name: equivalence

words.def: A category is equivalent to another category if there is an equivalence between them.
words.name: equivalent

words.def: A functor F is called essentially surjective (or isomorphism-dense) if for every object B there exists an object A such that F(A) is isomorphic to B.
words.name: essentially surjective

words.def: A functor is faithful if it is injective when restricted to each hom-set.
words.name: faithful

words.def: A functor π: C → D is said to exhibit C as a category fibered over D if, for each morphism g: x → π(y) in D, there exists a π-cartesian morphism f: x' → y in C such that π(f) = g. If D is the category of affine schemes (say of finite type over some field), then π is more commonly called a prestack. Note: π is often a forgetful functor and in fact the Grothendieck construction implies that every fibered category can be taken to be that form (up to equivalences in a suitable sense).
words.name: fibered category

words.def:
Given a category C and a set I, the fiber product over an object S of a family of objects Xi in C indexed by I is the product of the family in the slice category 
  
    
      
        
          C

            S

        S
      
    
    {\displaystyle X_{i}\to S}
  
). The fiber product of two objects X and Y over an object S is denoted by 
  
    
      
        X
        
          ×
          
            S
          
        
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle X\times _{S}Y}
  
 and is also called a Cartesian square.
words.name: fiber product

words.def:
1.  A filtered category (also called a filtrant category) is a nonempty category with the properties (1) given objects i and j, there are an object k and morphisms i → k and j → k and (2) given morphisms u, v: i → j, there are an object k and a morphism w: j → k such that w ∘ u = w ∘ v. A category I is filtered if and only if, for each finite category J and functor f: J → I, the set 
  
    
      
        
          
            
              lim
              
                
              
            
            ←

        Hom

        f
        (
        j
        )
        ,
        i
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \varprojlim \operatorname {Hom} (f(j),i)}
  
 is nonempty for some object i in I.
words.name: filtered

words.def: A category is finite if it has only finitely many morphisms.
words.name: finite

words.def:
The forgetful functor is, roughly, a functor that loses some of data of the objects; for example, the functor 
  
    
      
        
          G
          r
          p
        
        →
        
          S
          e
          t
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mathbf {Grp} \to \mathbf {Set} }
  
 that sends a group to its underlying set and a group homomorphism to itself is a forgetful functor.
words.name: forgetful functor

words.def: See Fukaya category.
words.name: Fukaya category

words.def: 1.  A functor is full if it is surjective when restricted to each hom-set.
words.name: full

words.def:

. For example,

,

 by

.
words.name: functor

words.def: The functor category Fct(C, D) from a category C to a category D is the category where the objects are all the functors from C to D and the morphisms are all the natural transformations between the functors.
words.name: functor category

words.def: The Gabriel–Popescu theorem says an abelian category is a quotient of the category of modules.
words.name: Gabriel–Popescu theorem

words.def:
In a category C, a family of objects 
  
    
      
        
          G
          
            i
          
        
        ,
        i
        ∈
        I
      
    
    {\displaystyle G_{i},i\in I}
  
 is a system of generators of C if the functor 
  
    
      
        X
        ↦
        
          ∏
          
            i
            ∈
            I
          
        
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        
          G
          
            i
          
        
        ,
        X
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle X\mapsto \prod _{i\in I}\operatorname {Hom} (G_{i},X)}
  
 is conservative. Its dual is called a system of cogenerators.
words.name: generator

words.def: A Grothendieck category is a certain well-behaved kind of an abelian category.
words.name: Grothendieck category

words.def:
Given a functor 
  
    
      
        U
        :
        C
        →
        
          C
          a
          t
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle U:C\to \mathbf {Cat} }
  
, let DU be the category where the objects are pairs (x, u) consisting of an object x in C and an object u in the category U(x) and a morphism from (x, u) to (y, v) is a pair consisting of a morphism f: x → y in C and a morphism U(f)(u) → v in U(y). The passage from U to DU is then called the Grothendieck construction.
words.name: Grothendieck construction

words.def: A fibered category.
words.name: Grothendieck fibration

words.def: 1.  A category is called a groupoid if every morphism in it is an isomorphism.
words.name: groupoid

words.def: See Ringel–Hall algebra.
words.name: Hall algebra of a category

words.def:
The heart of a t-structure (
  
    
      
        
          D
          
            ≥
            0
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle D^{\geq 0}}
  
, 
  
    
      
        
          D
          
            ≤
            0
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle D^{\leq 0}}
  
) on a triangulated category is the intersection 
  
    
      
        
          D
          
            ≥
            0
          
        
        ∩
        
          D
          
            ≤
            0
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle D^{\geq 0}\cap D^{\leq 0}}
  
. It is an abelian category.
words.name: heart

words.def: The homological dimension of an abelian category with enough injectives is the least non-negative intege n such that every object in the category admits an injective resolution of length at most n. The dimension is ∞ if no such integer exists. For example, the homological dimension of ModR with a principal ideal domain R is at most one.
words.name: homological dimension

words.def: See homotopy category. It is closely related to a localization of a category.
words.name: homotopy category

words.def:
1.  The identity morphism f of an object A is a morphism from A to A such that for any morphisms g with domain A and h with codomain A, 
  
    
      
        g
        ∘
        f
        =
        g
      
    
    {\displaystyle g\circ f=g}
  
 and 
  
    
      
        f
        ∘
        h
        =
        h
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\circ h=h}
  
.
words.name: identity

words.def:
The image of a morphism f: X → Y is the equalizer of 
  
    
      
        Y
        ⇉
        Y
        
          ⊔
          
            X
          
        
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle Y\rightrightarrows Y\sqcup _{X}Y}
  
.
words.name: image

A colimit (or inductive limit) in

          c
          t

          C

          S

.
words.name: ind-limit

words.def:
An ∞-category C is a simplicial set satisfying the following condition: for each 0 < i < n,

every map of simplicial sets 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        
          Λ
          
            i
          
          
            n
          
        
        →
        C

 extends to an n-simplex 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        
          Δ
          
            n
          
        
        →
        C
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:\Delta ^{n}\to C}
  


where Δn is the standard n-simplex and 
  
    
      
        
          Λ
          
            i
          
          
            n
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \Lambda _{i}^{n}}
  
 is obtained from Δn by removing the i-th face and the interior (see Kan fibration#Definition). For example, the nerve of a category satisfies the condition and thus can be considered as an ∞-category.
words.name: ∞-category

words.def: 1.  An object A is initial if there is exactly one morphism from A to each object; e.g., empty set in Set.
words.name: initial

words.def:
An object A in an abelian category is injective if the functor 
  
    
      
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        −
        ,
        A
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} (-,A)}
  
 is exact. It is the dual of a projective object.
words.name: injective

words.def:
Given a monoidal category (C, ⊗), the internal Hom is a functor 
  
    
      
        [
        −
        ,
        −
        ]
        :
        
          C
          
            op
          
        
        ×
        C
        →
        C
      
    
    {\displaystyle [-,-]:C^{\text{op}}\times C\to C}
  
 such that 
  
    
      
        [
        Y
        ,
        −
        ]
      
    
    {\displaystyle [Y,-]}
  
 is the right adjoint to 
  
    
      
        −
        ⊗
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle -\otimes Y}
  
 for each object Y in C. For example, the category of modules over a commutative ring R has the internal Hom given as 
  
    
      
        [
        M
        ,
        N

          Hom
          
            R

        M
        ,
        N
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle [M,N]=\operatorname {Hom} _{R}(M,N)}
  
, the set of R-linear maps.
words.name: internal Hom

words.def:
A morphism f is an inverse to a morphism g if 
  
    
      
        g
        ∘
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle g\circ f}
  
 is defined and is equal to the identity morphism on the codomain of g, and 
  
    
      
        f
        ∘
        g
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\circ g}
  
 is defined and equal to the identity morphism on the domain of g. The inverse of g is unique and is denoted by g−1. f is a left inverse to g if 
  
    
      
        f
        ∘
        g
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\circ g}
  
 is defined and is equal to the identity morphism on the domain of g, and similarly for a right inverse.
words.name: inverse

words.def: 1.  An object is isomorphic to another object if there is an isomorphism between them.
words.name: isomorphic

words.def: A morphism f is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse of f.
words.name: isomorphism

words.def: An object in an abelian category is said to have finite length if it has a composition series. The maximum number of proper subobjects in any such composition series is called the length of A.[5]
words.name: length

words.name: limit

words.def: See localization of a category.
words.name: localization of a category

words.def:
A morphism f is a monomorphism (also called monic) if 
  
    
      
        g
        =
        h
      
    
    {\displaystyle g=h}
  
 whenever 
  
    
      
        f
        ∘
        g
        =
        f
        ∘
        h
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\circ g=f\circ h}
  
; e.g., an injection in Set. In other words, f is the dual of an epimorphism.
words.name: monomorphism

words.def:
1.  A natural transformation is, roughly, a map between functors. Precisely, given a pair of functors F, G from a category C to category D, a natural transformation φ from F to G is a set of morphisms in D

            x

        G
        (

        x

        Ob

        (
        C
        )
        }
      
    
    {\displaystyle \{\phi _{x}:F(x)\to G(x)|x\in \operatorname {Ob} (C)\}}
  


satisfying the condition: for each morphism f: x → y in C, 
  
    
      
        
          ϕ
          
            y
          
        
        ∘
        F
        (
        f
        )
        =
        G
        (
        f
        )
        ∘
        
          ϕ
          
            x

. For example, writing 
  
    
      
        G
        
          L
          
            n
          
        
        (
        R
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle GL_{n}(R)}
  
 for the group of invertible n-by-n matrices with coefficients in a commutative ring R, we can view

            n

 as a functor from the category CRing of commutative rings to the category Grp of groups. Similarly,

 is a functor from CRing to Grp. Then the determinant det is a natural transformation from 
  
    
      
        G
        
          L
          
            n
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle GL_{n}}
  
 to -*.
words.name: natural

words.def:
The nerve functor N is the functor from Cat to sSet given by 
  
    
      
        N
        (
        C
        
          )
          
            n
          
        
        =
        
          Hom
          
            
              C
              a
              t
            
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        [
        n
        ]
        ,
        C
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle N(C)_{n}=\operatorname {Hom} _{\mathbf {Cat} }([n],C)}
  
.
words.name: nerve

words.def: A category is normal if every monic is normal.[citation needed]
words.name: normal

words.def: 1.  An object is part of a data defining a category.
words.name: object

words.def: A functor π:C → D is an op-fibration if, for each object x in C and each morphism g : π(x) → y in D, there is at least one π-coCartesian morphism f: x → y' in C such that π(f) = g. In other words, π is the dual of a Grothendieck fibration.
words.name: op-fibration

words.def: The opposite category of a category is obtained by reversing the arrows. For example, if a partially ordered set is viewed as a category, taking its opposite amounts to reversing the ordering.
words.name: opposite

words.def: Sometimes synonymous with "compact". See perfect complex.
words.name: perfect

words.def: A category (or ∞-category) is called pointed if it has a zero object.
words.name: pointed

words.def: A functor from the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces to itself is called a polynomial functor if, for each pair of vector spaces V, W, F: Hom(V, W) → Hom(F(V), F(W)) is a polynomial map between the vector spaces. A Schur functor is a basic example.
words.name: polynomial

words.def: A category is preadditive if it is enriched over the monoidal category of abelian groups. More generally, it is R-linear if it is enriched over the monoidal category of R-modules, for R a commutative ring.
words.name: preadditive

words.def: Given a regular cardinal κ, a category is κ-presentable if it admits all small colimits and is κ-accessible. A category is presentable if it is κ-presentable for some regular cardinal κ (hence presentable for any larger cardinal). Note: Some authors call a presentable category a locally presentable category.
words.name: presentable

words.def: Another term for a contravariant functor: a functor from a category Cop to Set is a presheaf of sets on C and a functor from Cop to sSet is a presheaf of simplicial sets or simplicial presheaf, etc. A topology on C, if any, tells which presheaf is a sheaf (with respect to that topology).
words.name: presheaf

words.def:
1.  The product of a family of objects Xi in a category C indexed by a set I is the projective limit 
  
    
      
        
          
            
              lim
              
                
              
            
            ←
          
          
            
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \varprojlim }
  
 of the functor 
  
    
      
        I
        →
        C
        ,
        
        i
        ↦
        
          X
          
            i
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle I\to C,\,i\mapsto X_{i}}
  
, where I is viewed as a discrete category. It is denoted by 
  
    
      
        
          ∏
          
            i
          
        
        
          X
          
            i
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \prod _{i}X_{i}}
  
 and is the dual of the coproduct of the family.
words.name: product

words.def:
An object A in an abelian category is projective if the functor 
  
    
      
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        A
        ,
        −
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Hom} (A,-)}
  
 is exact. It is the dual of an injective object.
words.name: projective

words.def: Quillen’s theorem A provides a criterion for a functor to be a weak equivalence.
words.name: Quillen

words.def: 1.  A functor is said to reflect identities if it has the property: if F(k) is an identity then k is an identity as well.
words.name: reflect

words.def:
A set-valued contravariant functor F on a category C is said to be representable if it belongs to the essential image of the Yoneda embedding 
  
    
      
        C
        →
        
          F
          c
          t
        
        (
        
          C
          
            op
          
        
        ,
        
          S
          e
          t
        
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle C\to \mathbf {Fct} (C^{\text{op}},\mathbf {Set} )}
  
; i.e., 
  
    
      
        F
        ≃
        
          Hom
          
            C
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        −
        ,
        Z
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle F\simeq \operatorname {Hom} _{C}(-,Z)}
  
 for some object Z. The object Z is said to be the representing object of F.
words.name: representable

words.def:
f is a retraction of g. g is a section of f.


A morphism is a retraction if it has a right inverse.
words.name: retraction

words.def: A morphism is a section if it has a left inverse. For example, the axiom of choice says that any surjective function admits a section.
words.name: section

words.def: Segal spaces were certain simplicial spaces, introduced as models for (∞, 1)-categories.
words.name: Segal space

words.def: An abelian category is semisimple if every short exact sequence splits. For example, a ring is semisimple if and only if the category of modules over it is semisimple.
words.name: semisimple

words.def: An object in an abelian category is simple if it is not isomorphic to the zero object and any subobject of A is isomorphic to zero or to A.
words.name: simple

words.def: Simplicial localization is a method of localizing a category.
words.name: Simplicial localization

words.def: A simplicial set is a contravariant functor from Δ to Set, where Δ is the category whose objects are the sets [n] = { 0, 1, …, n } and whose morphisms are order-preserving functions. A morphism between simplicial sets is a natural transformation.
words.name: simplicial set

words.def: A category is skeletal if isomorphic objects are necessarily identical.
words.name: skeletal

words.def:
Given a category C and an object A in it, the slice category C/A of C over A is the category whose objects are all the morphisms in C with codomain A, whose morphisms are morphisms in C such that if f is a morphism from 
  
    
      
        
          p
          
            X
          
        
        :
        X
        →
        A
      
    
    {\displaystyle p_{X}:X\to A}
  
 to 
  
    
      
        
          p
          
            Y
          
        
        :
        Y
        →
        A
      
    
    {\displaystyle p_{Y}:Y\to A}
  
, then 
  
    
      
        
          p
          
            Y
          
        
        ∘
        f
        =
        
          p
          
            X
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle p_{Y}\circ f=p_{X}}
  
 in C and whose composition is that of C.
words.name: slice

words.def: 1.  A small category is a category in which the class of all morphisms is a set (i.e., not a proper class); otherwise large. A category is locally small if the morphisms between every pair of objects A and B form a set. Some authors assume a foundation in which the collection of all classes forms a "conglomerate", in which case a quasicategory is a category whose objects and morphisms merely form a conglomerate.[6] (NB: some authors use the term "quasicategory" with a different meaning.[7])
words.name: small

words.def: An ∞-category is stable if (1) it has a zero object, (2) every morphism in it admits a fiber and a cofiber and (3) a triangle in it is a fiber sequence if and only if it is a cofiber sequence.
words.name: stable

words.def:
A morphism f in a category admitting finite limits and finite colimits is strict if the natural morphism 
  
    
      
        Coim
        ⁡
        (
        f
        )
        →
        Im
        ⁡
        (
        f
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle \operatorname {Coim} (f)\to \operatorname {Im} (f)}
  
 is an isomorphism.
words.name: strict

words.def: A strict 0-category is a set and for any integer n > 0, a strict n-category is a category enriched over strict (n-1)-categories. For example, a strict 1-category is an ordinary category. Note: the term "n-category" typically refers to "weak n-category"; not strict one.
words.name: strict n-category

words.def: A topology on a category is subcanonical if every representable contravariant functor on C is a sheaf with respect to that topology.[8] Generally speaking, some flat topology may fail to be subcanonical; but flat topologies appearing in practice tend to be subcanonical.
words.name: subcanonical

words.def: A category A is a subcategory of a category B if there is an inclusion functor from A to B.
words.name: subcategory

words.def: See subobject. For example, a subgroup is a subobject of a group.
words.name: subobject

words.def: A subquotient is a quotient of a subobject.
words.name: subquotient

words.def: A subterminal object is an object X such that every object has at most one morphism into X.
words.name: subterminal object

words.def: A symmetric monoidal category is a monoidal category (i.e., a category with ⊗) that has maximally symmetric braiding.
words.name: symmetric monoidal category

words.def: A t-structure is an additional structure on a triangulated category (more generally stable ∞-category) that axiomatizes the notions of complexes whose cohomology concentrated in non-negative degrees or non-positive degrees.
words.name: t-structure

words.def: Usually synonymous with monoidal category (though some authors distinguish between the two concepts.)
words.name: tensor category

words.def:
Given a monoidal category B, the tensor product of functors 
  
    
      
        F
        :
        
          C
          
            op
          
        
        →
        B
      
    
    {\displaystyle F:C^{\text{op}}\to B}
  
 and 
  
    
      
        G
        :
        C
        →
        B
      
    
    {\displaystyle G:C\to B}
  
 is the coend:


  
    
      
        F
        
          ⊗
          
            C
          
        
        G
        =
        
          ∫
          
            c
            ∈
            C
          
        
        F
        (
        c
        )
        ⊗
        G
        (
        c
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle F\otimes _{C}G=\int ^{c\in C}F(c)\otimes G(c)}
  
.
words.name: tensor product

words.def: 1.  An object A is terminal (also called final) if there is exactly one morphism from each object to A; e.g., singletons in Set. It is the dual of an initial object.
words.name: terminal

words.def: A full subcategory of an abelian category is thick if it is closed under extensions.
words.name: thick subcategory

words.def: A thin is a category where there is at most one morphism between any pair of objects.
words.name: thin

words.def: A triangulated category is a category where one can talk about distinguished triangles, generalization of exact sequences. An abelian category is a prototypical example of a triangulated category. A derived category is a triangulated category that is not necessary an abelian category.
words.name: triangulated category

words.def:
1.  Given a functor 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        C
        →
        D
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:C\to D}
  
 and an object X in D, a universal morphism from X to f is an initial object in the comma category 
  
    
      
        (
        X
        ↓
        f
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle (X\downarrow f)}
  
. (Its dual is also called a universal morphism.) For example, take f to be the forgetful functor 
  
    
      
        
          
            V
            e
            c
          
          
            k
          
        
        →
        
          S
          e
          t
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mathbf {Vec} _{k}\to \mathbf {Set} }
  
 and X a set. An initial object of 
  
    
      
        (
        X
        ↓
        f
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle (X\downarrow f)}
  
 is a function 
  
    
      
        j
        :
        X
        →
        f
        (
        
          V
          
            X
          
        
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle j:X\to f(V_{X})}
  
. That it is initial means that if 
  
    
      
        k
        :
        X
        →
        f
        (
        W
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle k:X\to f(W)}
  
 is another morphism, then there is a unique morphism from j to k, which consists of a linear map 
  
    
      
        
          V
          
            X
          
        
        →
        W
      
    
    {\displaystyle V_{X}\to W}
  
 that extends k via j; that is to say, 
  
    
      
        
          V
          
            X
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle V_{X}}
  
 is the free vector space generated by X.
words.name: universal

words.def: A Waldhausen category is, roughly, a category with families of cofibrations and weak equivalences.
words.name: Waldhausen category

words.def: A category is wellpowered if for each object there is only a set of pairwise non-isomorphic subobjects.
words.name: wellpowered

words.def:
The Yoneda lemma says: For each set-valued contravariant functor F on C and an object X in C, there is a natural bijection


  
    
      
        F
        (
        X
        )
        ≃
        Hom
        ⁡
        (
        
          Hom
          
            C
          
        
        ⁡
        (
        −
        ,
        X
        )
        ,
        F
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle F(X)\simeq \operatorname {Hom} (\operatorname {Hom} _{C}(-,X),F)}
  
;

in particular, the functor


  
    
      
        C
        →
        
          F
          c
          t
        
        (
        
          C
          
            op

    {\displaystyle C\to \mathbf {Fct} (C^{\text{op}},\mathbf {Set} ),\,X\mapsto \operatorname {Hom} _{C}(-,X)}
  


is fully faithful.[9]
words.name: Yoneda lemma

words.def: A zero object is an object that is both initial and terminal, such as a trivial group in Grp.
words.name: zero
